justification: The text states, “Hyperbolic discounting is widely used to quantify individual differences in delay discounting (Odum, 2011).”

The article introduces the “classical model of Samuelson (1937)” describing exponential discounting as a way to capture how subjective value declines with delay, directly linking this function to the study of delay discounting.
Table 1 lists the “Scaled exponential (beta-delta; Laibson, 1997)” function among the “Popular discount functions” used to model delay discounting.
Table 1 includes the “Nonlinear-time exponential (Ebert and Prelec, 2007)” function as one of the commonly used formulations for discounting future rewards.
Table 1 presents the “Dual-systems exponential (Van den Bos and McClure, 2013)” model as a recognised discount function for characterising delay discounting behaviour.
The caption for Table 1 notes the “Inverse q-exponential (Green and Myerson, 2004)” as another function “commonly used” to describe delay discounting patterns.
Table 1 lists the “Nonlinear-time hyperbolic (Rachlin, 2006)” formulation, indicating it as a standard tool for modelling delay discounting.
